natural problem: How many ways are there to arrange 6 people around a circular table with 7 seats?  (Two seatings are considered the same if one is a rotation of the other.)
natural solution: First choose which seat is empty. It doesn't matter which seat we choose because we can rotate everyone at the table to move the empty seat anywhere we want. After the empty seat has been chosen, there are $6!=\boxed{720}$ ways to arrange the remaining people.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes people seats :: nat and ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "people = 6"
and h1 : "seats = 7"
and h2 : "ways = (fact (seats - 1)) div (fact (seats - people - 1))"
shows  "ways = 720"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange 6 people around a circular table with 7 seats?  (Two seatings are considered the same if one is a rotation of the other.) The final Answer is 720
 ### Proof
 First choose which seat is empty. It doesn't matter which seat we choose because we can rotate everyone at the table to move the empty seat anywhere we want. After the empty seat has been chosen, there are $6!=\boxed{720}$ ways to arrange the remaining people.
 *)

theorem
fixes people seats :: nat and ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "people = 6"
and h1 : "seats = 7"
and h2 : "ways = (fact (seats - 1)) div (fact (seats - people - 1))"
shows  "ways = 720"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A group of 6 people is to be seated in a row of 7 seats. How many different ways can they be seated? The final answer is 720.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes people seats :: nat and arrangements :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "people = 6"
and h1 : "seats = 7"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. arrangements n = fact n div n"
shows  "arrangements people = 720"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange 6 people around a circular table with 7 seats?  (Two seatings are considered the same if one is a rotation of the other.) The final Answer is 720
 ### Proof
 First choose which seat is empty. It doesn't matter which seat we choose because we can rotate everyone at the table to move the empty seat anywhere we want. After the empty seat has been chosen, there are $6!=\boxed{720}$ ways to arrange the remaining people.
 *)

theorem
fixes people seats :: nat and arrangements :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "people = 6"
and h1 : "seats = 7"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. arrangements n = fact n div n"
shows  "arrangements people = 720"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: How many ways can 6 people be arranged in 7 seats? The final answer is 720.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and perm :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat set"
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "card (perm n) = fact n"
and h2 : "\<forall> p1 p2. p1 \<in> perm n \<and> p2 \<in> perm n \<and> (\<exists> k. \<forall> i. p1 i = p2 ((i + k) mod n)) \<longrightarrow> p1 = p2"
shows  "card {p. p \<in> perm n \<and> (\<forall> p2. p2 \<in> perm n \<and> (\<exists> k. \<forall> i. p i = p2 ((i + 1) mod n)) \<longrightarrow> p = p2)} = 720"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange 6 people around a circular table with 7 seats?  (Two seatings are considered the same if one is a rotation of the other.) The final Answer is 720
 ### Proof
 First choose which seat is empty. It doesn't matter which seat we choose because we can rotate everyone at the table to move the empty seat anywhere we want. After the empty seat has been chosen, there are $6!=\boxed{720}$ ways to arrange the remaining people.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and perm :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat set"
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "card (perm n) = fact n"
and h2 : "\<forall> p1 p2. p1 \<in> perm n \<and> p2 \<in> perm n \<and> (\<exists> k. \<forall> i. p1 i = p2 ((i + k) mod n)) \<longrightarrow> p1 = p2"
shows  "card {p. p \<in> perm n \<and> (\<forall> p2. p2 \<in> perm n \<and> (\<exists> k. \<forall> i. p i = p2 ((i + 1) mod n)) \<longrightarrow> p = p2)} = 720"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a set of 6 elements, there are 720 (6!) possible permutations. How many unique permutations are there such that no two permutations can be obtained from one another by a cyclic shift (i.e., shifting all elements to the right by a fixed number of positions)? The final answer is 720.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 7"
and h1 : "k = 6"
shows  "card {P. permutation P \<and> (\<forall>i<k. P i < n)} = 720"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange 6 people around a circular table with 7 seats?  (Two seatings are considered the same if one is a rotation of the other.) The final Answer is 720
 ### Proof
 First choose which seat is empty. It doesn't matter which seat we choose because we can rotate everyone at the table to move the empty seat anywhere we want. After the empty seat has been chosen, there are $6!=\boxed{720}$ ways to arrange the remaining people.
 *)

theorem
fixes n k :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 7"
and h1 : "k = 6"
shows  "card {P. permutation P \<and> (\<forall>i<k. P i < n)} = 720"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: How many permutations are there of length 6, where each element is an integer less than 7? The final answer is 720.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes count_arrangements :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "count_arrangements 6 7 = 720"
shows  "count_arrangements 6 7 = 720"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange 6 people around a circular table with 7 seats?  (Two seatings are considered the same if one is a rotation of the other.) The final Answer is 720
 ### Proof
 First choose which seat is empty. It doesn't matter which seat we choose because we can rotate everyone at the table to move the empty seat anywhere we want. After the empty seat has been chosen, there are $6!=\boxed{720}$ ways to arrange the remaining people.
 *)

theorem
fixes count_arrangements :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "count_arrangements 6 7 = 720"
shows  "count_arrangements 6 7 = 720"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the number of arrangements for 6 items taken 7 at a time. The final answer is 720.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
shows  "fact n = 720"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange 6 people around a circular table with 7 seats?  (Two seatings are considered the same if one is a rotation of the other.) The final Answer is 720
 ### Proof
 First choose which seat is empty. It doesn't matter which seat we choose because we can rotate everyone at the table to move the empty seat anywhere we want. After the empty seat has been chosen, there are $6!=\boxed{720}$ ways to arrange the remaining people.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
shows  "fact n = 720"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: What is the factorial of 6? The final answer is 720.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes circular_arrangements :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "circular_arrangements = (\<lambda>n. fact (n - 1))"
shows  "circular_arrangements 6 = 720"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange 6 people around a circular table with 7 seats?  (Two seatings are considered the same if one is a rotation of the other.) The final Answer is 720
 ### Proof
 First choose which seat is empty. It doesn't matter which seat we choose because we can rotate everyone at the table to move the empty seat anywhere we want. After the empty seat has been chosen, there are $6!=\boxed{720}$ ways to arrange the remaining people.
 *)

theorem
fixes circular_arrangements :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "circular_arrangements = (\<lambda>n. fact (n - 1))"
shows  "circular_arrangements 6 = 720"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In how many ways can 6 objects be arranged in a circle? The final answer is 720.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n seats :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "seats = 7"
and h2 : "seats >= n"
shows  "fact n = 720"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange 6 people around a circular table with 7 seats?  (Two seatings are considered the same if one is a rotation of the other.) The final Answer is 720
 ### Proof
 First choose which seat is empty. It doesn't matter which seat we choose because we can rotate everyone at the table to move the empty seat anywhere we want. After the empty seat has been chosen, there are $6!=\boxed{720}$ ways to arrange the remaining people.
 *)

theorem
fixes n seats :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "seats = 7"
and h2 : "seats >= n"
shows  "fact n = 720"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: There are 6 people and 7 seats available. Assuming that each person can sit in any of the available seats, how many different ways can the 6 people be seated? The final answer is 720.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes seats people :: nat
assumes h0 : "seats = 7"
and h1 : "people = 6"
shows  "card {P :: nat set. card P = people \<and> (\<forall> i j. i \<in> P \<and> j \<in> P \<and> i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> (i + 1) mod seats \<noteq> j)} = 720"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange 6 people around a circular table with 7 seats?  (Two seatings are considered the same if one is a rotation of the other.) The final Answer is 720
 ### Proof
 First choose which seat is empty. It doesn't matter which seat we choose because we can rotate everyone at the table to move the empty seat anywhere we want. After the empty seat has been chosen, there are $6!=\boxed{720}$ ways to arrange the remaining people.
 *)

theorem
fixes seats people :: nat
assumes h0 : "seats = 7"
and h1 : "people = 6"
shows  "card {P :: nat set. card P = people \<and> (\<forall> i j. i \<in> P \<and> j \<in> P \<and> i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> (i + 1) mod seats \<noteq> j)} = 720"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: In a circular arrangement of 7 seats, how many ways can 6 people be seated such that no two people are sitting next to each other? The final answer is 720 ways.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes people seats :: nat
assumes h0 : "people = 6"
and h1 : "seats = 7"
shows  "card {p :: nat list. length p = people \<and> distinct p \<and> set p \<subseteq> {1..seats}} div people = 720"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange 6 people around a circular table with 7 seats?  (Two seatings are considered the same if one is a rotation of the other.) The final Answer is 720
 ### Proof
 First choose which seat is empty. It doesn't matter which seat we choose because we can rotate everyone at the table to move the empty seat anywhere we want. After the empty seat has been chosen, there are $6!=\boxed{720}$ ways to arrange the remaining people.
 *)

theorem
fixes people seats :: nat
assumes h0 : "people = 6"
and h1 : "seats = 7"
shows  "card {p :: nat list. length p = people \<and> distinct p \<and> set p \<subseteq> {1..seats}} div people = 720"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: How many ways can 6 people be seated in 7 available seats? The final answer is 720.
